Comment: So I start with my usual.
He invites a Caro-Kann, which would arise if I play 2. e4, and he replies with d5. I am sure he knows more about it than me, so I avoid that!
So I invite a Slav defence with d5
But he avoids that and opts for a Dutch Defence.
So I develop.
He does the natural developing move too.
And me also.
He opts for a Leningrad formation, with his bishop on g7 rather than playing e7-e6 and developing it along the f8-a3 diagonal.
I continue to develop.
As does he.
So I grab the centre.
He takes.
I take back.
He castles.
I play the natural developing move too. I am planning 0-0 and Ne2-c3 to back up the knight on e4.
So he takes before I can get the knight round.
I take back. e4 is a lovely square for one of my minor pieces, but it would be even better to have a knight on this square rather than a bishop.
I am not sure about this move. After my next, the range of his Bg7 is limited, and my minor piece on e4 is unable to be shifted by a pawn.
So I close up the position.
This move surprised me. He has pressure on f2 and b2, but is this move really better than simple development such as d6?
